Award.AwardTitle: MARGINS: Collaborative Research: Illuminating the Architecture of the Greater Mount St. Helens Magmatic System from Slab to Surface
Award.AbstractNarration:
To better understand volcanic activity, it is fundamental to get an accurate representation of magma generation zones and storage regions in the Earth?s crust and upper mantle. Illuminating the architecture of the plumbing system beneath volcanoes will allow scientists to determine (1) at which depths and conditions magmas are generated, and (2) the shapes and sizes of pathways and reservoirs along which magma travels towards the surface. Such knowledge will allow scientists to make more informed predictions on the durations of volcanic crises and on the total volume of erupted material during eruptive episodes.

This project focuses on the Mount St. Helens volcanic edifice, (WA, USA), whose explosive eruption in 1980 attracted world?s attention, and was the first volcano to be thoroughly monitored with modern instruments. Mount St. Helens provides an ideal setting to apply state-of-the-art geophysical and geochemical techniques to image its subterranean roots: It is active, easily accessible, and has a well recorded past history. The project will use several different methods (active and passive source seismic tomography and scattered wave imaging, magnetotelluric imaging, petrology and geochemistry), involving a large collaborative team, to image the volcano?s plumbing system with unprecedented resolution from the subducting plate to the surface. The results will be informative for many other volcanoes around the world, particularly those located along the infamous Pacific Ring of Fire.

POR.DRECONTENT:
To better understand volcanic activity, scientists need to understand where magma is generated and stored in the Earth’s crust and upper mantle. For several decades, volcanology has been successful at monitoring activity in the uppermost crust, where deformation and magma motion occur in the minutes to days before eruptions. However, these magmas are almost always created deeper, and travel through a poorly-understood plumbing system from the lower crust and upper mantle. The goals of this project are to illuminate the architecture of the plumbing system beneath volcanoes to determine (1) at which depths and conditions magmas are generated, and (2) the shapes and sizes of pathways and reservoirs along which magma travels towards the surface. Such knowledge could allow scientists to make more informed predictions on the durations of volcanic unrest and on the total volume of erupted material during eruptive episodes.

 

This project focuses on the magmas that ascend to Mount St. Helens volcanic edifice (WA, USA). Its explosive eruption in 1980 attracted world’s attention, and was the first volcano to be thoroughly monitored with modern instruments. Mount St. Helens provides an ideal setting to apply state-of-the-art geophysical and geochemical techniques to image its subterranean roots: It is active, easily accessible, and has a well recorded past history. The project uses several different methods (active and passive source seismic tomography and scattered wave imaging, magnetotelluric imaging, petrology and geochemistry), involving a large collaborative team, to image the volcano’s plumbing system with unprecedented resolution from the subducting plate to the surface. The results provide information about many other volcanoes around the world, particularly those located along the infamous Pacific Ring of Fire.

 

For the seismic imaging part of this project, an array was deployed 70 high-quality broadband seismographs in a wide area around Mount St. Helens, extending 50 km in all directions and covering the Indian Heaven volcanic field to the east. This is perhaps the densest, largest array of this kind deployed around an active volcano. This deployment lasted two years, 2014-2016.

 

The Cornell group has led the effort to image the deeper system, using signals from distant earthquakes and the Earth’s background seismic noise. One study provides the first images of the subducting plate directly beneath Mount St. Helens. It shows that a typical oceanic plate (the Juan de Fuca plate) descending beneath the volcano here, but the plate is only 68 km deep directly beneath the volcano. In most places the subducting plate is 100 km deep beneath arc volcanoes. This small depth means the mantle melting region is very small, calling into questions assumptions about how Mount St. Helens (and other arc volcanoes) are related to subduction. Second, by examining the earth’s ambient noise generated by distant ocean waves striking shorelines, the speed of seismic waves beneath the array can be evaluated in great detail. These studies show that the crust beneath the Washington Cascades undergoes a sharp change between an oceanic plateau geology near the coast, to more typical silica-rich continental compositions behind the arc. This transition happens abruptly at the location of Mount St. Helens, showing that crustal geology may control some part of the magma plumbing system. A third study, of the absorption of seismic waves directly beneath seismometers, reveals a sharp boundary between absorbing, hot conditions everywhere east of Mount St. Helens with apparently cold conditions immediately west of it. These observations combined with other non-seismic observations show that the mantle directly beneath Mount St. Helens is too cold to produce the magmas that erupt, and it seems unlikely that magma exists directly beneath the volcano more than about 10-15 km deep, even though geochemistry indicates magma comes from deeper. Magma must migrate laterally through the crust here, farther than has been documented in any other arc volcano. The reasons for this migration are unclear but show that the deep source for volcanoes may not always be beneath them, but displaced tens of km to the side.
